obnubilus: <entryFree id="n31754" type="hapax" key="obnu_bi^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nūbĭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n31754.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., overclouded, cloudy, dark, obscure</hi>: obnubila tenebris loca, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:21:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 21, 48</bibl> (Trag. v. 108 Vahl.).</sense></entryFree>
obnubo: <entryFree id="n31755" type="main" key="obnu_bo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nūbo</orth>, <itype>psi, ptum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31755.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to veil, cover</hi> (very rare; syn.: velo, induo, amicio). </sense><sense id="n31755.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: LICTOR, CONLIGA MANVS, CAPVT OBNVBITO, ARBORI INFELICI SVSPENDITO, an old formula ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 4, 13</bibl>: flammeo caput nubentis obvolvatur, quod antiqui obnubere vocarint ... legem jubere caput ejus obnubere qui parentem necavisset, quod est obvolvere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=170" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 170</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:2:254" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 2, 254</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ca put tempestate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:11:259" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 11, 259</bibl></cit>: comas amictu <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 77</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Absol., to veil the head</hi> <pb n="1239" /> <cb n="OBOE" /> obnubit, caput operit, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=184" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 184</bibl> Müll.—* </sense><sense id="n31755.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare terras obnubit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=72" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 72</bibl></cit> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
obnuntiatio: <entryFree id="n31756" type="main" key="obnunti^a_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnuntĭātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obnunc-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obnuntio</etym>, in the lang. of augurs, <sense id="n31756.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an announcement of an opposing, adverse, evil omen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dirarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:16:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 16, 29</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">obnuntiationibus per Scaevolam interpositis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comitiorum cotidie singuli dies tolluntur obnuntiationibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 3, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnuntio: <entryFree id="n31757" type="main" key="obnuntio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-nuntio</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-nuncio</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n31757.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To tell, report, announce</hi> any thing bad or unfortunate: <cit><quote lang="la">primus rescisco omnia: Primus porro obnuntio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31757.1" n="II" level="1"> In augury, t. t., <hi rend="ital">to announce an opposing, adverse</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">evil omen</hi> (used both of the augurs and of the magistrates and tribunes of the people; cf. Smith's Antiq.): proprie obnuntiare dicuntur augures, qui aliquid mali ominis scaevumque viderint, Don. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">augur auguri, consul consuli obnuntiāsti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:33:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 33, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fretus sanctitate tribunatūs obnuntiavit consuli, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:37:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 37, 79</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sibi postero die in foro obnuntiaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 3, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obnuptus: <entryFree id="n31758" type="main" key="obnuptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obnuptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obnubo.</entryFree>
oboediens: <entryFree id="n31759" type="main" key="o^boedi^ens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedĭens</orth>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedĭenter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. oboedio, <sense id="n31759.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
oboedientia: <entryFree id="n31760" type="main" key="o^boedi^enti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedĭentĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obed-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>oboediens</etym>, <sense id="n31760.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">obedience</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31760.1" n="A" level="2"> Of persons. </sense><sense id="n31760.2" n="1" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">servitus est oboedientia fracti animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:1:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 5, 1, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31760.3" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">relinquunt enim et abiciunt oboedientiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 29</bibl></cit>. 102.—</sense><sense id="n31760.4" n="B" level="2"> Of bees: <cit><quote lang="la">mira plebi circa regem oboedientia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 17, 17, § 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31760.5" n="C" level="2"> Of elephants: <cit><quote lang="la">intellectus illis sermonis patrii et imperiorum oboedientia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 1, 1, § 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
oboedio: <entryFree id="n31761" type="main" key="o^boedi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-oedĭo</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ēdĭo</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:29:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 29, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Ep. ad Verr. 7" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Ep. ad Verr. 7</bibl> Mai.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Fer. Als. 3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fer. Als. 3</bibl>; cf.: oboedire, obaudire, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll. and Bramb. s. v.— Ante-class. form of the <sense id="n31761.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fut.</hi>, oboedibo: oboedibo tibi, Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 507, 30</bibl>), īvi or <itype>ĭi, ītum, īre, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>ob-audio</etym>. </sense><sense id="n31761.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (very rare), <hi rend="ital">to give ear, hearken, listen to</hi> one: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 5, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31761.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n31761.3" n="A" level="2"> Prop., of living beings (class.). </sense><sense id="n31761.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To obey, yield obedience to. to be subject to, to serve</hi> (freq. and class.; cf.: pareo, obtempero, obsequor).—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">parere, et oboedire praecepto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:12:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 12, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:8:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 8, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obtemperare et oboedire magistratibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:2:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui nobis oboediunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:29:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 29, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impulsu libidinum voluptatibus oboedientium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 26, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecora ventri oboedientia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multorum oboedire tempori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:69:242" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 69, 242</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrimque enixe oboeditum dictatori est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31761.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To be obedient in</hi> any thing (post-class.).—With <hi rend="ital">acc. of neutr. pron.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque haec omnia perfacile oboediebam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 247, 11</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:29" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31761.6" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, of things, <hi rend="ital">to yield, be manageable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ramus oleae quam maxime sequax, atque oboediturus,</quote> <trans><tr>yielding, flexible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 19, 30, § 137</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedĭens</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ŏbēd-</orth>), <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n31761.7" n="A" level="2"> Prop., of living beings, <hi rend="ital">obedient, compliant</hi> (freq. and class.). </sense><sense id="n31761.8" n="1" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulli est naturae oboediens aut subjectus deus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:30:77" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 30, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natio semper oboediens huic imperio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:34:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 34, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">appetitum rationi oboedientem praebere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:36:132" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 36, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vivere oboedientem alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31, 26</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperiis nemo oboedientior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:38:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 38, 7</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperiis oboedientissimus miles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 13, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31761.9" n="2" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad nova consilia gentem oboedientem habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 16</bibl></cit>.—Particular phrases. </sense><sense id="n31761.10" n="a" level="4"> Dicto oboedientem esse alicui for dicto audientem esse alicui, <hi rend="ital">to be obedient to one's word</hi> or <hi rend="ital">command</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magistro desinebat esse dicto oboediens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 35</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nec plebs nobis dicto audiens atque oboediens sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 7</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31761.11" n="b" level="4"> Omnia secunda et oboedientia sunt, <hi rend="ital">according to your wishes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 19</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31761.12" n="3" level="3"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus vis omnis in consensu oboedientium esset,</quote> <trans><tr>the obedient</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:59:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 59, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31761.13" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of things, <hi rend="ital">yielding, manageable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oboedientissima quocumque in opere fraxinus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>easily wrought</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:228" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 43, 83, § 228</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedĭ-enter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">obediently, willingly, readily</hi> (a favorite word of Livy; elsewh. very rare): <cb n="OBRE" /> conferre tributum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere imperata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere adversus aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 39, 53</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil oboedientius fecerunt, quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 34</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: oboedientissime paruit, Aug. Civ. Dei, 22, 8.</sense></entryFree>
oboeditio: <entryFree id="n31762" type="main" key="o^boedi_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏboedītĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obed-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>oboedio</etym>, <sense id="n31762.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">obedience</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">per unius oboeditionem justi constituentur multi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Rom. 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad justitiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> de Fug. Saec. 2, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
oboleo: <entryFree id="n31763" type="main" key="o^bo^le^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ŏlĕo</orth>, <itype>ŭi, 2</itype>, <sense id="n31763.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to smell of</hi> any thing (ante-class. and post-Aug.). </sense><sense id="n31763.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">oboluisti allium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 1, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maluissem allium oboluisses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antidotum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 23</bibl></cit>: res mihi obolet. <hi rend="ital">I smell a thing</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 311, 31</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31763.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam oboluit Casina procul,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:4:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 4, 3, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">marsupium huic oboluit,</quote> <trans><tr>she smells your purse</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 3, 33</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obolus: <entryFree id="n31764" type="greek" key="o^bo^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbŏlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">o)bolo/s</foreign>. <sense id="n31764.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an obol, a small Greek coin, the sixth part of a drachm</hi>, equivalent to three and a half cents Federal currency, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">siclus viginti obolos habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:30:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 30, 13</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31764.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, as a weight, <hi rend="ital">the sixth part of a drachm</hi> Fann. de Ponder. et Mens. 37; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 34, 109, § 185</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:142" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 12, 91, § 142</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">trium obolorum pondere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 25, 96, § 169</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obominatus: <entryFree id="n31765" type="main" key="o^bo_mi^na_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ōmĭnātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from the obsol. obominor, <sense id="n31765.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wishing ill to</hi> one (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">crurum ei fragium obominata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 227, 36</bibl></cit> (al. abominata).</sense></entryFree>
oborior: <entryFree id="n31766" type="main" key="o^bo^ri^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ŏrĭor</orth>, <itype>ortus, 4</itype>, <sense id="n31766.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep., to arise, appear, spring up</hi> (class.): oboritur, nascitur, nam praepositionem ob pro ad, solitam poni, testis hic versus: tantum gaudium oboriri ex tumultu maximo, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=190" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 190</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">tenebrae oboriuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimis ita fatur obortis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:181" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 181</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laetitia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 2</bibl></cit>: vide, quanta lux liberalitatis et sapientiae mihi apud te dicenti oboriatur, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:34" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caligo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 19</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. 1, p. 29</bibl></cit> Oud.</sense></entryFree>
oborsus: <entryFree id="n31767" type="gloss" key="o^borsus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-orsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from the obsol. obordior, <sense id="n31767.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">beginning</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">orsus, oborsus, exorsus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 151</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obortus: <entryFree id="n31768" type="main" key="o^bortus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ortus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from oborior.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31769" type="spur" key="o^bortus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-ortus</orth>, a false read. for odores, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 218</bibl>; v. Lachm. ad h. l.</entryFree>
obosculor: <entryFree id="n31770" type="main" key="o^boscu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏb-oscŭlor</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31770.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep., to kiss</hi> (postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">quae flagellorum vestigia obosculantur (al. osculantur),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 126</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obp: <entryFree id="n31771" type="main" key="obp"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obp-</orth>, v. opp-.</entryFree>
obquinisco: <entryFree id="n31772" type="main" key="obquinisco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-quinisco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, v. ocquinisco.</entryFree>
obradio: <entryFree id="n31773" type="main" key="obra^di^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rădĭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n31773.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to shine forth</hi> (postclass.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 16, 18, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obraucatus: <entryFree id="n31774" type="main" key="obrauca_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obraucātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from the obsol. obrauco, āre [ob - raucus], <sense id="n31774.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">grown hoarse</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ea (grus) ubi obraucata est, succedit alia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 10, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obrendarius: <entryFree id="n31775" type="gloss" key="obrenda_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrendārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>for obruendarius, v. obruo</etym>, <sense id="n31775.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to burial, burial-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">VASA OBRENDARIA DVA,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>earthen sarcophagi</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4544</bibl></cit>. —Called also, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <itype>OBRENDARIVM, ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 607, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obrepilatio: <entryFree id="n31776" type="main" key="obre_pi^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrēpĭlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obrepo</etym> (late Lat.), Vita <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> Arel. 2, 1, 2</bibl>.</entryFree>
obrepo: <entryFree id="n31777" type="main" key="obre_po"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rēpo</orth>, <itype>psi, ptum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31777.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to creep up</hi> to any thing, <hi rend="ital">approach stealthily</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31777.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">et possim mediā quamvis obrepere nocte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:9" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit> (8), 59; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:10:2" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 10, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui Gallos in obsidione Capitolii obrepentes per ardua depulerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:21:24" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 21, 24</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">feles quam levibus vestigiis obrepunt avibus!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 73, 94, § 202</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31777.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31777.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to steal upon, come suddenly upon</hi> one; <hi rend="ital">to take by surprise, to surprise</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31777.4" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui enim citius adulescentiae senectus, quam pueritiae adulescentia obrepit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 2, 4</bibl></cit>: mihi decessionis dies <foreign lang="greek">lelhqo/tws</foreign> obrepebat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 5, 3</bibl>; cf. in the foll. under <foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui obrepsit oblivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 3:2:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 3, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitia nobis sub virtutum nomine obrepunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 45:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 45, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31777.5" n="(b)" level="5"> With <case>acc.</case> (ante-class., and in Sall.): <cit><quote lang="la">tacitum te obrepet fames,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si tanta torpedo animos obrepsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:49:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 49, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31777.6" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Plancium non obrepsisse ad honorem,</quote> <trans><tr>to creep up to, to come at by stealth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 7, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obrepsisti ad honores errore hominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 1, 1</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31777.7" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: imagines obrepunt<cb n="OBRO" />  in animos dormientium extrinse cus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:67:139" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 67, 139</bibl>; Ambros. Off. Mi. nist. 3, 6, 41.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">obrepsit dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obrepit non intellecta senectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:129" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 129</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31777.8" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">to surprise, deceive, cheat</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam tu, credo, me imprudentem obrepseris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 132</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:10" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:12:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 12, 4</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si obreptum praetori sit de libertate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:5:26:section=8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 5, 26, § 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:7:55:section=4" default="NO">26, 7, 55, § 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obrepticius: <entryFree id="n31778" type="main" key="obrepti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptīcĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obrepo</etym>, <sense id="n31778.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">surreptitious, obreptitious</hi> (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">petitio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 3, 6, 3</bibl></cit>; Cod. Th. 4, 22, 6 (al. obrepta).</sense></entryFree>
obreptio: <entryFree id="n31779" type="main" key="obrepti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31779.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a creeping</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stealing on, a coming on suddenly</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by surprise, a surprise</hi> (post - Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">Ventidius, aggressus per obreptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Strat. 2:5:36" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Strat. 2, 5, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, 162</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arrogari per obreptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:4:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: precum, Cod. Th. 5, 8, 1. —<usg type="style">Transf.</usg> (eccl. Lat.), <hi rend="ital">a surprise by sudden temptation</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> in Luc. 10, § 72</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obreptive: <entryFree id="n31780" type="main" key="obrepti_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptīvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obreptivus <sense id="n31780.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obreptivus: <entryFree id="n31781" type="main" key="obrepti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obrepo</etym>, <sense id="n31781.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">secret, clandestine</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">supplicatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 5:64" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 5, 64</bibl></cit>; Cod. Th. 16, 10, 8.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptīvē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">surreptitiously, clandestinely</hi> (post-class.): aut clanculo supplicare, Cod. Th. 16, 1, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obrepto: <entryFree id="n31782" type="main" key="obrepto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrepto</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31782.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq. n.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to steal on unawares, to come on imperceptibly</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">ne quis obreptaverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obreptantibus Satyris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 109</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 5, 3</bibl>, the correct read. is obrepebat).</sense></entryFree>
obreptus: <entryFree id="n31783" type="main" key="obreptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obreptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obripio; v. obrepticius.</entryFree>
obretio: <entryFree id="n31784" type="main" key="obre_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrētĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi or ĭi, ītum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ob-rete</etym>. <sense id="n31784.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to eatch in a net, to entangle</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:384" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 384</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obrigesco: <entryFree id="n31785" type="main" key="obri^gesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rĭgesco</orth>, <itype>găi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31785.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to stiffen, become stiff</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31785.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31785.2" n="a" level="4"> With <case>abl.</case>: pars obrigescit frigore, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 97, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pars (terrae regionum) obriguerit nive, pruināque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:10:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 10, 24</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">e quibus (cingulis) duos obriguisse pruinā vides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:20:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 20, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31785.3" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: fructus per pruinam obriguerint, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 6</bibl> Müll. (acc. to Trag. Rel. p. 64 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum jam paene obriguisset, vix vivus aufertur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:40:section=87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 40, § 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obrigesceret cum gladio,</quote> <trans><tr>become stiff with holding</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:23:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 23, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31785.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to grow hard, become hardened</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">viro non vel obrigescere satius est?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 82:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 82, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obrimas: <entryFree id="n31786" type="main" key="Obri^mas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obrĭmas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31786.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Phrygia Major, which flows into the Mæander</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 106</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Obrimae fontes, conj. reading for Rhotrinos fontes (the latter name being unknown),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:15:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 15, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obroboratio: <entryFree id="n31787" type="main" key="o^bro_bo^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ŏbrōbŏrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ob-roboro</etym>, <sense id="n31787.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">rigidity of the nerves</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Vet. 3, 85</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obrodo: <entryFree id="n31788" type="main" key="obro_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rōdo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n31788.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to gnaw</hi> (ante- and post-class. for mordeo). </sense><sense id="n31788.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vermis te semper obrodit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Tob. 7, § 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quod obrodat sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 92</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31788.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to gnaw over, chew upon; to backbite, depreciate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec sunt argumentationis ossa, quae obroditis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 2, 5 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacrilego morsu pretiosum fidei velamen obrodunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ambros.</author> Spir. Sanct. 1, 16, 164</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frequenter obrodi a maledicis obtrectatoribus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> in Psa. 118</bibl></cit>, Serm. 8, 36.</sense></entryFree>
obrogatio: <entryFree id="n31789" type="main" key="obro^ga_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrŏgātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obrogo</etym>, <sense id="n31789.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a motion partly to repeal</hi> or <hi rend="ital">alter one law by another, an obrogation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum duae leges inter se differunt, videndum est, num qua obrogatio aut derogatio sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 10, 15</bibl></cit>; cf. obrogo.</sense></entryFree>
obrogo: <entryFree id="n31790" type="main" key="obro^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rŏgo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n31790.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Partly to repeal an existing law by proposing a new one, to evade, weaken, invalidate, abrogate</hi> it: obrogare est legis prioris infirmandae causā legem aliam ferre, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 187</bibl> Müll.: obrogatur, id est mutatur aliquid ex primā lege, Ulp. tit. 1, 3; <cit><quote lang="la">v. abrogo: huic legi nec obrogari fas est, neque derogari ex hac aliquid licet, neque tota abrogari potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:22:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 22, 33</bibl></cit> Mos.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid, quod obrogatur legibus Caesaris, quae jubent? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:9:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 9, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia ubi duae contrariae leges sunt, semper antiquae obrogat nova,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:34:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 34, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud 23</bibl>: cf. id <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31790.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To oppose the passage of a bill</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">obrogare auso iegibus suis Minucio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:15:4" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 15, 4</bibl></cit>; cf.: <pb n="1240" /> <cb n="OBRY" /> ausus obrogare de legibus consul Philippus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:17:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 17, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obructans: <entryFree id="n31791" type="hapax" key="obructans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obructans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> from the obsol. obructo [ob-ructo], <sense id="n31791.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belching at</hi> one: <cit><quote lang="la">tibi obructans,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 312, 34</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obruo: <entryFree id="n31792" type="main" key="obru^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-rŭo</orth>, <itype>ŭi, ŭtum, 3</itype> (<sense id="n31792.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inf. pres. pass.</hi> OBRI for obrui, Inscr. Marin. Fratr. Arv. p. 341; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">in the foll.</ref></xr> I. B. 1.), <pos>v. a.</pos> (<gen>n.</gen> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:775" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 775</bibl>; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>), <hi rend="ital">to overwhelm, overthrow, strike down; to cover, cover over</hi> with any thing; also <hi rend="ital">to hide in the ground, bury</hi> by heaping over (class.; cf.: opprimo, subruo). </sense><sense id="n31792.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31792.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem caestu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 191</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concidit, et totis fratrem gravis obruit armis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:573" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Th. 11, 573</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:692" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 692</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">confossus undique obruitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ranae marinae dicuntur obruere sese harenā solere,</quote> <trans><tr>bury themselves in the sand</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:49:125" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 49, 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">thesaurum,</quote> <trans><tr>to bury</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:7:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ova,</quote> <trans><tr>to hide in the earth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:52:129" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 52, 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegros veste,</quote> <trans><tr>to cover</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 3, 8, § 16</bibl></cit>: oceanum rubra tractim obruit aethra, <hi rend="ital">covered</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 4</bibl> (Ann. v. 418 Vahl.); so, <cit><quote lang="la">terram nox obruit umbris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:864" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 864</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31792.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">to bury, inter</hi> a dead body (perh. only post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 29 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cadaver levi caespite obrutum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:59" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 59</bibl></cit>: cujus ossa in Vulcanali obruta sunt, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. statua, p. 290 Müll.: QVOD SE VOLVIT OBRI. Inscr. Marin. Fratr. Arv. p. 341.—</sense><sense id="n31792.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To sink</hi> in the sea, <hi rend="ital">cover with water</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">puppes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos Obruit Auster,</quote> <trans><tr>overwhelmed, sunk</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 336</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:9:2:29" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 9, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obrutus adulter aquis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Her. 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obruerit cum tot deus aequoris undis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:6:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 3, 6, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:2:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegyptum Nilus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31792.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To sow</hi> seed; <hi rend="ital">cover with earth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">semina terrā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 173</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">milium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:72" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lupinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 2, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">betam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:3:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 3, 42</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31792.6" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To overload, surfeit</hi> with any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">se vino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31792.7" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31792.8" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To overwhelm, bury, conceal, put out of sight, abolish, consign to oblivion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut adversā quasi perpetuā oblivione obruamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:17:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 17, 57</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ea quae umquam vetustas obruet aut quae tanta delebit oblivio?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 13, 37</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">(sermo) nec umquam de ullo perennis fuit, et obruitur hominum interitu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:23:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 23, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">talis viri interitu sex suos obruere consulatus,</quote> <trans><tr>to dim, cloud, destroy the glory of six consulships</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:19:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 19, 56</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31792.9" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et domus aetatis spatio ne fessa vetusto obruat,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>fall to ruin</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:775" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 775</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31792.10" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To overwhelm, overload, weigh down, oppress</hi> with any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">criminibus obrutus atque oppressus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:7:section=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 7, § 20</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">copiā sententiarum atque verborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambitione, et foro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:21:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 21, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aere alieno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 1, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">faenore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:7" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnitudine negotii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:1:section=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 1, § 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31792.11" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To overcome, overpower, surpass, eclipse, obscure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">famam alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obruimur numero,</quote> <trans><tr>are outnumbered</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:424" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 424</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obruit Idaeam quantum tuba Martia buxum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:320" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 320</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">M. Brutus Vatinium dignatione obruerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:69" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Venus Nymphas obruit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 293</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obrussa: <entryFree id="n31793" type="greek" key="obrussa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrussa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (pure Gr. collat. form = <foreign lang="greek">xrusi/on o)/bruzon</foreign>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obrȳzum aurum</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Par. 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> 16, 18, 2</bibl>), <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">o)/bruzon</foreign>, <sense id="n31793.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the testing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assaying of gold by fire in a cupel</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31793.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">auri experimentum ignis est: id ipsum obrussam vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 3, 19, § 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum ad obrussam,</quote> <trans><tr>refined, pure gold</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 44</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31793.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a test, touchstone, proof</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibenda tamquam obrussa ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:74:258" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 74, 258</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic verus ille animus probatur: haec ejus obrussa est,</quote> <trans><tr>this is its touchstone, its test</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 13:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 13, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si omnia argumenta ad obrussam coeperimus exigere,</quote> <trans><tr>to put to the proof, test accurately</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4:5:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. N. 4, 5, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obrutesco: <entryFree id="n31794" type="main" key="obru_tesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrūtesco</orth>, v. obbrutesco.</entryFree>
obrutus: <entryFree id="n31795" type="main" key="obru^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrŭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obruo.</entryFree>
obryza: <entryFree id="n31796" type="main" key="obry_za"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrȳza</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (collat. form of obrȳzum aurum), <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n31796.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">standard gold</hi>, Cod. 12, 6, 12; 12, 7, 3; v. obrussa <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obryzatus: <entryFree id="n31797" type="main" key="obry_za_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrȳzātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obryzum</etym>, <sense id="n31797.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">made of standard gold</hi> (post-class.), Cod. Th. 11, 10, 3; 12, 49, 1.</sense></entryFree>
obryzum: <entryFree id="n31798" type="main" key="obry_zum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obrȳzum</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">obrī-</orth>, also written <orth extent="full" lang="la">obry-zum aurum</orth>), = <foreign lang="greek">o)/bruzon</foreign> (sc. <foreign lang="greek">xrusi/on</foreign>), <sense id="n31798.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pure gold</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Par. 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 67</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 28, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">31, 24</bibl>; cf. obrussa <hi rend="ital">init.</hi> <cb n="OBSC" /></sense></entryFree>
obsaepio: <entryFree id="n31799" type="main" key="obsaepi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-saepĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ob-sēpĭo</orth>), <itype>psi, ptum, 4</itype> (old form obsipio, Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 378</bibl> P.), <sense id="n31799.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to hedge</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fence in, to enclose;</hi> hence, transf., <hi rend="ital">to close up, to render impassable</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inaccessible</hi> (class.; syn.: obstruo, oppilo). </sense><sense id="n31799.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: NEQVE QVIS IN EO LOCO QVID OPPONIT, MOLIT, OBSEPIT, FIGIT, etc., S. C. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aquaed. 129" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aquaed. 129</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi illum saltum video obsaeptum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Casin. 5, 2, 35</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">obsaeptis itineribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 29</bibl></cit>; v. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mox iter, apertis, quae vetustas obsaepserat, pergit,</quote> <trans><tr>had rendered impassable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsaepta viarum,</quote> <trans><tr>impassable roads</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:110" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 110</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31799.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to close</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bar up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec omnia tibi accusandi viam muniebant, adipiscendi obsaepiebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:23:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 23, 48</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">id. Scaur. § 40: plebi iter ad curules magistratus obsaepsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsaepta diutinā servitute ora reseramus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:66" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 66</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsalutare: <entryFree id="n31800" type="gloss" key="obsa^lu_ta_re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsălūtāre</orth>, <itype>se offerre salutandi gratiā dicebant antiqui, ut consalutare, persalutare</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
obsatullo: <entryFree id="n31801" type="main" key="obsa^tullo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sătullo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n31801.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dim. a.</hi> [saturo], <hi rend="ital">to sate</hi>: obstrudant, obsatullent, Poët. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll. (Com. Rel. v. 73 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
obsaturo: <entryFree id="n31802" type="hapax" key="obsa^tu^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sătŭro</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n31802.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to sate, cloy, glut;</hi> trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">ne tu propediem istius obsaturabere,</quote> <trans><tr>you'll soon have enough of him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:8:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 8, 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obscaen: <entryFree id="n31803" type="main" key="obscaen"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscaen-</orth>, v. obscen-.</entryFree>
obscaevo: <entryFree id="n31804" type="hapax" key="obscaevo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscaevo</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>ob-scaeva</etym>, <sense id="n31804.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to give</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring a bad omen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo, quod illic obscaevavit meae falsae fallaciae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 1, 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obscene: <entryFree id="n31805" type="main" key="obsce_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnē</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">obscaenē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscoe-nē</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obscenus <sense id="n31805.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obscenitas: <entryFree id="n31806" type="main" key="obsce_ni^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnĭtas</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">obscaen-, obscoen-</orth>), <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obscenus</etym>. * <sense id="n31806.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Unfavorableness, inauspiciousness</hi>, of a bad omen: <cit><quote lang="la">mali ominis obscenitas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31806.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Moral impurity, foulness, unchastity, lewdness, obscenity</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31806.2" n="A" level="2"> In abstr. (the class. signif. of the word): <cit><quote lang="la">si rerum turpitudo adhibetur et verborum obscenitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:104" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 29, 104</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 35, 127</bibl>; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:59:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 59, 242</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quod sit in obscenitate flagitium, id aut in re esse aut in verbo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:22:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 22, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenitas non a verbis tantum abesse debet, sed etiam a significatione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eques Romanus obscenitatis in feminas reus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">professis apud se obscenitatem cetera quoque concessisse delicta,</quote> <trans><tr>unchastity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenitate oris hirsuto atque olido seni clare exprobrata,</quote> <trans><tr>the disfigurement produced by lewdness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in obscenitatem, aliquem compellere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:12:1:section=8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 12, 1, § 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31806.3" n="B" level="2"> Concr., <hi rend="ital">an obscene thing</hi> (post-Aug. and very rare): corporum obscenitas, = <foreign lang="greek">ta\ ai)doi=a</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, 176</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amputata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 173</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in poculis libidines caelare juvit ac per obscenitates bibere,</quote> <trans><tr>obscene figures</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:H. N 30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> H. N 30</bibl></cit> prooem. § 5.</sense></entryFree>
obscenus: <entryFree id="n31807" type="main" key="obsce_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">obscaen-</orth>, and less properly <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscoen-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>perh. ob and caenum, filth</etym>, <sense id="n31807.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of adverse, unfavorable, evil omen; ill-boding, inauspicious, ominous, portentous</hi> (cf.: sinister, funestus): apud antiquos omnes fere obscena dicta sunt, quae mali ominis habebantur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=201" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 201</bibl> Müll.: obsceni interpres funestique ominis auctor, Matius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=96" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 96</bibl> Müll.; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 357, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">deūm rixa vertat verba obscena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:ib. 357:17" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> ib. 357, 17</bibl></cit>; Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 8, 361</bibl> (Ann. v. 182 Vahl.): montem istum (Aventinum) excluserunt, quasi avibus obscenis ominosum (viz., by reason of the birds, which gave unfavorable omens to Remus), Mess. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:14:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 14, 6</bibl>; so, volucres, <hi rend="ital">birds of illomen</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">owls</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:876" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 876</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">canes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:470" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 470</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenum ostentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:55:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 55, 140</bibl></cit>: puppis, <hi rend="ital">the fatal ship</hi>, that bore Helen when she eloped with Paris to Troy, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:5:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 5, 119</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Troja,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anus,</quote> <trans><tr>old witches, hags</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:98" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 98</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: Alliesis dies dicebatur apud Romanos obscenissimi ominis, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. Alliesis, p. 7 Müll.—</sense><sense id="n31807.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">repulsive, offensive, abominable, hateful, disgusting, filthy</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31807.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen. (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: immundus, turpis): (Allecto) frontem obscenam rugis arat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 417</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volucres pelagi,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the harpies</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 241</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">262: upupa, obscena alias pastu avis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 29, 44, § 86</bibl></cit>; cf. <cb n="OBSC" /> fames, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:367" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 367</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haustus,</quote> <trans><tr>of filthy water</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:312" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 312</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cruor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:455" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 455</bibl></cit>.— As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the excrements</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 8:1:20" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 8, 1, 20</bibl>; also, <hi rend="ital">the urine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui clam latuit reddente obscena puellā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 437</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31807.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic., offensive to modesty, i. e. <hi rend="ital">immodest, impure, indecent, lewd, obscene</hi> (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: spurcus, impurus): delicatae et obscenae voluptates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:40:111" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 40, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulterium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:212" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 212</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenas tabellas pingere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:5:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 5, 19</bibl></cit> (6, 27): <cit><quote lang="la">carmina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:16:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 16, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gestus motusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenum in modum formata commotaque manus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>so as to suggest impure thoughts</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:56" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jocandi genus flagitiosum, obscenum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:104" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 29, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si obscena nudis nominibus enuntientur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:38" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quodque facere turpe non est, modo occulte, id dicere obscenum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35:127" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35, 127</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> § 128; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:125" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 125</bibl>. —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud Antipatri paulo obscenius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:38:112" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 38, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abjectior et obscenior vita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 5</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.—Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenissimi versus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:83:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 83, 2</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n31807.4" n="2" level="3"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n31807.5" n="(a)" level="5"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a lewd person</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis enim non vicus abundat Tristibus obscenis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:9" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31807.6" n="(b)" level="5"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, less freq. in the <number>sing.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnum</orth>, i. <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the private parts</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">ta\ ai)doi=a</foreign>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nymphe fugiens obscena Priapi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:347" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 347</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pars nudi agunt, pars tantum obscena velati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:58" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscena corporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:631" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 631</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 21, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epit. 23, 8</bibl>; Jul. Obsequ. 84.—Hence, <itype>also</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obscēnē</orth> (acc. to II. B), <hi rend="ital">impurely, indecently, lewdly, obscenely</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">latrocinari, fraudare, adulterare, re turpe est, sed dicitur non obscene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35:128" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35, 128</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (Mercurii) obscenius excitata natura traditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:22:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 22, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscenius concurrerent litterae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:45:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 45, 154</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">impudicissime et obscenissime vixit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 8, 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obscuratio: <entryFree id="n31808" type="main" key="obscu_ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscūrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obscuro</etym>, <sense id="n31808.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a darkening, obscuring, obscuration</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31808.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: solis, Cic. Fragm. ap. Aug. Civ. Dei, 5, 15; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:10:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 10, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 27, 69, § 202</bibl>: in illā obscuratione, <hi rend="ital">darkness, obscurity</hi>, Auct. B. Hisp. 6.—</sense><sense id="n31808.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quibus (voluptatibus) propter earum exiguitatem, obscuratio consequitur,</quote> <trans><tr>an obscuring, a rendering invisible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:12:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 12, 29</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 13, 32</bibl>; cf. obscuro.</sense></entryFree>
obscure: <entryFree id="n31809" type="main" key="obscu_re_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscūrē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obscurus <sense id="n31809.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obscurefacio: <entryFree id="n31810" type="hapax" key="obscu_re^fa^ci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscūrĕfăcĭo</orth> (only in pres.), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>obscurus-facio</etym>, for obscuro, <sense id="n31810.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to obscure, render invisible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblitterare est obscurefacere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 146, 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obscuritas: <entryFree id="n31811" type="main" key="obscu_ri^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscūrĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obscurus</etym>, <sense id="n31811.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a being dark, darkness, obscurity</hi>. </sense><sense id="n31811.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (perh. only post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">latebrarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 18, 16, § 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">visūs,</quote> <trans><tr>dimness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 1, 20, § 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 3, 12, § 51</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31811.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> (class.), <hi rend="ital">obscurity, indistinctness, uncertainty</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut oratio, quae lumen adhibere rebus debet, ea obscuritatem et tenebras afferat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:13:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 13, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pythagorae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:10:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 10, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscuritas fit etiam vet is ab usu remotis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:2:12" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eā obscuritate ac dubitatione omnium,</quote> <trans><tr>uncertainty</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:27:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 27, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:5:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 5, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:18:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 18, 35</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo pertinent obscuritates et aenigmata somniorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:64:132" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 64, 132</bibl></cit>: obscuritates non adsignemus culpae scribentium, sed inscientiae non adsequentium, Caecil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscuritatibus involutum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31811.3" n="B" level="2"> Of rank, <hi rend="ital">obscurity, lowliness, meanness</hi>: quorum prima aetas propter humilitatem et obscuritatem, in hominum ignoratione versatur. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 13, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sordes et obscuritatem Vitellianarum partium perstringemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">generis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:1:13" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec obscuritas inhibuit (Servium Tullium), quamvis matre servā creatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:6:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 6, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obscuro: <entryFree id="n31812" type="main" key="obscu_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obscūro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31812.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to render dark, to darken, obscure</hi> (class.; syn.: obumbro, opaco). </sense><sense id="n31812.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscuratur et offunditur luce solis lumen lucernae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:14:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 14, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nitor solis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:66:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 66, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">finitimas regiones eruptione Aetnaeorum ignium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:N. D. 2:38:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 38, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelum nocte atque nubibus obscuratum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 38:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 38, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volucres Aethera obscurant pennis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 253</bibl></cit>: nebula caelum obscurabat, Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 489, 10</bibl>: obscuratus sol, <hi rend="ital">obscured</hi>, <pb n="1241" /> <cb n="OBSC" /> <hi rend="ital">eclipsed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:16:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 16, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 10, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:24:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 24, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Apoc. 9, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 11</bibl>, ext. 1: <cit><quote lang="la">visus obscuratus,</quote> <trans><tr>dimmed eyesight</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 27, 41, § 99</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31812.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to hide, conceal, cover; to render invisible</hi> or <hi rend="ital">imperceptible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque nox tenebris obscurare coetus nefarios potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput obscurante lacernā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput dextra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 134</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolo ipsi et signa militaria obscurati,</quote> <trans><tr>concealed, kept out of sight</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 49:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 49, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummus in Croesi divitiis obscuratur,</quote> <trans><tr>disappears, is lost</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:12:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 12, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenebrae non obscurabuntur a te,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:138:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 138, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31812.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31812.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To blind, darken, becloud</hi> the understanding: <cit><quote lang="la">scio amorem tibi Pectus obscurasse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 41</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31812.5" n="B" level="2"> Of speech, <hi rend="ital">to obscure, render indistinct; to deliver</hi> or <hi rend="ital">express indistinctly</hi>: si erunt mihi plura ad te scribenda, <foreign lang="greek">a)llhgori/ais</foreign> obscurabo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:20:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 20, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil dicendo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid callide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:41" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 41</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:2:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 2, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">stilum affectatione,</quote> <trans><tr>to render obscure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:70" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 70</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31812.6" n="C" level="2"> Of sound, <hi rend="ital">to pronounce indistinctly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(M) neque eximitur sed obscuratur,</quote> <trans><tr>is pronounced indistinctly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:40" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 40</bibl></cit>: vocem, <hi rend="ital">to render dull</hi> or <hi rend="ital">indistinct</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 3, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31812.7" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To obscure, cover with obscurity;
