(only ante-class. and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">hoc ego fui hodie solus obsessor fori,</quote> <trans><tr>sai in the forum alone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 18</bibl></cit>: vivarum aquarum (of <hi rend="ital">a water-snake</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:259" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 259</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31852.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic., milit., <hi rend="ital">a besieger, invester, blockader</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsessor curiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Luceriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:15:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 15, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus pavoris obsessis quam obsessoribus intulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 73</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsessus: <entryFree id="n31853" type="main" key="obsessus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsessus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obsideo.</entryFree>
obsianus: <entryFree id="n31854" type="main" key="Obsi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obsĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Obsius.</entryFree>
obsibilo: <entryFree id="n31855" type="main" key="obsi_bi^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sībĭlo</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31855.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to whistle away, to rustle</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">arbores dulces strepitus obsibilabant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 260, 27</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsidatus: <entryFree id="n31856" type="main" key="obsi^da_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>obses</etym>, <sense id="n31856.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the condition of a hostage, hostageship</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">pater ejus diu obsidatūs pignore tentus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 12, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidatūs sorte in Syriis detentus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 18, 6, 20</bibl></cit>: in obsidatum datus, Schol. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:164" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 164</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsideo: <entryFree id="n31857" type="main" key="obsi^de^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sĭdĕo</orth>, <itype>ēdi, essum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n31857.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi> [sedeo]. </sense><sense id="n31857.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr., to sit, stay, remain, abide</hi> anywhere (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">servi ne obsideant, liberis ut sit locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domi obsidere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 6, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in limine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:2:237" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 2, 237</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31857.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act., to sit at, on</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">in, to remain on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in, to haunt, inhabit, frequent</hi> a place. </sense><sense id="n31857.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">aram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 3, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ranae stagna et rivos obsident,</quote> <trans><tr>frequent marshes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 18, 19, § 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsedit limina bubo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:636" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 636</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Apollo umbilicum terrarum obsidet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 56</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31857.4" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31857.5" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="dom">Milit. t. t.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to sit down before, to hem in, beset, besiege, invest, blockade</hi> a place (cf. oppugno): <cit><quote lang="la">cum omnes aditus armati obsiderent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:35:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 35, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Curio Uticam obsidere instituit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consiliis ab oppugnandā urbe ad obsidendam versis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">propius inopiam erant obsidentes quam obsessi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Carthaginem crederent extemplo Scipionem obsessurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam Italiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:28:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 28, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vallis obsessa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">egregias Lateranorum aedīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:17" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 17</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31857.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To occupy, fill, possess</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">corporibus omnis obsidetur locus,</quote> <trans><tr>is filled</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:23:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 23, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatum armis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 7, 5, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">palus obsessa salictis,</quote> <trans><tr>full of osier-thickets</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:363" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 363</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Trachasque obsessa palude,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>surrounded</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:717" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 717</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31857.7" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to occupy, possess, take possession of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:42:4:21" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 42, 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui meum tempus obsideret,</quote> <trans><tr>who took up my time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:62:210" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 62, 210</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum obsideri aures a fratre cerneret,</quote> <trans><tr>that they were continually besieged by his brother</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 20 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n31857.8" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To have one's eye upon, to watch closely, be on the look-out for</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jacere humi ... ad obsidendum stuprum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:10:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 10, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rostra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 24, 57</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsidialis: <entryFree id="n31858" type="hapax" key="obsi^di^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obsidium</etym>, <sense id="n31858.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">for besieging, siege-</hi>: admotis obsidialibus machinamentis (al. obsidionalibus), Auct. Itin. Alex. 47 Mai.</sense></entryFree>
obsidianus: <entryFree id="n31859" type="spur" key="Obsi^di^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obsĭdĭānus</orth>, a false read. for Obsianus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 26, 67, § 196</bibl>; v. Obsius.</entryFree>
obsidio: <entryFree id="n31860" type="main" key="obsi^di^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obsideo</etym>. <sense id="n31860.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31860.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">a siege, investment, blockade</hi> of a place (class.): obsidionem potias dicendum esse, quam obsidium, adjuvat nos testimonio suo Ennius in Telamone, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=198" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 198</bibl> Müll.; v. Müll. ad loc.; and cf.: cui tu obsidionem paras, Enn. ib. (Trag. v. 365 <cb n="OBSI" /> Vahl.); and: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidionem obducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> (Trag. v. 11 ib.): <cit><quote lang="la">partim vi, partim obsidione urbes capere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 9, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem in obsidione habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum spes major Romanis in obsidione quam in oppugnatione esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 2</bibl></cit>: obsidione eximere, <hi rend="ital">to free</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relcase from</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidione cingere,</quote> <trans><tr>to besiege, blockade</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:4:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 22, 4, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidionem tolerare,</quote> <trans><tr>to stand</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidionem exsequi,</quote> <trans><tr>to carry on</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidionem omittere,</quote> <trans><tr>to raise</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 5</bibl></cit>: obsidionem solvere, <hi rend="ital">to put an end to a siege</hi>, by either surrender or relief: <cit><quote lang="la">tolerando paucos dies totam soluturos obsidionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:7:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 7, 8</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 20, 7, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">solutā obsidione,</quote> <trans><tr>raised</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:31:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 31, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:4:1" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 4, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eam obsidionem sine certamine adveniens Cn. Scipio solvit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:41:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 41, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:22:15" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 22, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:4:5" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 4, 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 34</bibl>: liberare obsidionem, <hi rend="ital">to raise the siege</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non ad Romam obsidendam, sed ad Capuae liberandam obsidionem Hannibalem ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 8, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. obsidium <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">longae dira obsidionis egestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:96" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 15, 96</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n31860.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">captivity</hi> (post-class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:12:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 12, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15:1:3" default="NO">15, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:1:1" default="NO">39, 1, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31860.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">pressing, imminent danger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidione rem publicam liberare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 10, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feneratores ex obsidione eximere,</quote> <trans><tr>to free from the danger of losing their money</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 6, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:81:2" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 81, 2</bibl>; cf. obsidium.</sense></entryFree>
obsidionalis: <entryFree id="n31861" type="main" key="obsi^di^o_na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭōnālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obsidio</etym>, <sense id="n31861.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a siege</hi>: corona, <hi rend="ital">a crown of grass, granted as a reward to a general who rescued others from siege</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=190" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 190</bibl> Müll.; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:37:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 37, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 4, 4, § 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:6:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 6, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Ill. 59" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Ill. 59</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">machinae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 24, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Strat. 1:3:4" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Strat. 1, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mala,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsidior: <entryFree id="n31862" type="main" key="obsi^di^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>obsidium</etym>, <sense id="n31862.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to lie in wait for, to waylay</hi> one (perh. only postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:14:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 14, 10</bibl></cit>.—(In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,029:page=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Scaur. p. 40</bibl>, instead of obsidietur, Mai. more correctly reads obsaepiatur; v. obsaepio.)</sense></entryFree>
obsidium: <entryFree id="n31863" type="main" key="obsi^di^um1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭum</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>obsideo</etym>, <sense id="n31863.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a siege, investment, blockade</hi> (mostly ante-class. and post-Aug. for obsidio; not in Cic. or Cæs.; but cf. obsidio). </sense><sense id="n31863.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidium dictum ab obsidendo, quominus hostis egredi posset inde,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=90" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 90</bibl></cit> Müll.: obsidium, tam quam praesidium, subsidium, recte dicitur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll.: saevo obsidio premere aliquem, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 216, 29</bibl> (Ann. v. 28 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">obsidium facere Ilio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidio circumdare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidium urgere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:4:4" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:31:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 31, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 20, 7, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad liberandum Mogontiaci obsidium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31863.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31863.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A waylaying, an ambush</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsidia hominum aut insidiosorum animalium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:2:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31863.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Attention, foresight</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">curatoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:9:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 9, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. obsidio.—</sense><sense id="n31863.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Danger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tuo tergo obsidium adesse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 64</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31864" type="hapax" key="obsi^di^um2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭdĭum</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>obses</etym>, <sense id="n31864.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the condition of a hostage, hostageship</hi> (Tacitean): <cit><quote lang="la">Meherdates obsidio nobis datus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsidius: <entryFree id="n31865" type="main" key="Obsi^di^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obsĭdĭus</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31865.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:18:7" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 18, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsido: <entryFree id="n31866" type="main" key="obsi_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sīdo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n31866.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to beset, invest, besiege, blockade</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): ne auriculam obsidat caries, ne vermiculique, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 21, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vias oculorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:351" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 351</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">certas partes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1092" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1092</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pontem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 45:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 45, 2</bibl></cit> Kritz <hi rend="ital">N. cr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">portas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 159</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Italos fines,</quote> <trans><tr>to occupy, take possession of</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 334</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedator cupit immensos obsidere campos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:3:41" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 3, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Troica moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:345" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 345</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsignatio: <entryFree id="n31867" type="main" key="obsigna_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsignātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obsigno</etym>, <sense id="n31867.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sealing, sealing up</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">testamenti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 4, 6, 1 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabularum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:2:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 2, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 81</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Bapt. 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsignator: <entryFree id="n31868" type="main" key="obsigna_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsignātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31868.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sealer, sealer up</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">litterarum obsignator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:66:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 66, 186</bibl></cit>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">the witnesses who set their seals to a will</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 13, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">testamenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12</bibl></cit> 18, b, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">decisionis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 36, 89</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsigno: <entryFree id="n31869" type="main" key="obsigno"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-signo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31869.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to seal, seal up</hi> a will, a letter, etc. (class.). </sense><sense id="n31869.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n31869.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">cedo tu ceram ac linum actutum: age obliga, obsigna cito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:4:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 4, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cellas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lagenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0478,001:Fam. 16:26" default="NO"><author>Q. Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">epistulam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:28:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 28, 71</bibl>.—Esp.: tabulas, <cb n="OBSO" /> testamenta, <hi rend="ital">to sign and seal</hi>, as a witness: <cit><quote lang="la">istam ipsam quaestionem, dicite, quis obsignavit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:66:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 66, 185</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabellas ejus rei condicionisque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 21, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">testamentum signis adulterinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:14:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 14, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsignavit anulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 6, 17</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: agere cum aliquo tabellis obsignatis, <hi rend="ital">to deal with one with sealed writings</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">in the strictest form</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:11:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 11, 33</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">tamquam ex syngraphā agere cum populo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:17:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 17, 35</bibl></cit>): tabulas obsignare velle, <hi rend="ital">would seal up the documents</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">would have no discussion</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:28:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 28, 69</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31869.3" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31869.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To seal up the papers and effects of an accused person</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:19:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 19, 50</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n31869.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To seal an accusation</hi> against one: qui contra Scaurum patrem suum obsignaverat, Cic. Scaur. Fragm. ap. Ascon.—</sense><sense id="n31869.6" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To pledge</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mortgage under one's hand and seal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tria agri jugera ad aerarium obsignaverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:4:7" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 4, 4, 7</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31869.7" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To close under seal, make fast</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inane obsignari nihil solere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:70:145" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 70, 145</bibl></cit>; cf. the context.—</sense><sense id="n31869.8" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to stamp, impress</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">formam verbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:567" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 567</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid obsignatum habere,</quote> <trans><tr>to impress on the mind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:581" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 581</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsipo: <entryFree id="n31870" type="main" key="obsi^po"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sĭpo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>supo</etym>, <sense id="n31870.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sprinkle at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon</hi> (ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">obsipat aquulam, prov.,</quote> <trans><tr>it refreshes, cheers me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 2, 3, 37</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsisto: <entryFree id="n31871" type="main" key="obsisto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sisto</orth>, <itype>stĭti, stĭtum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31871.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to set, place</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">post one's self before</hi> any thing (class.; syn.: adversor, repugno). </sense><sense id="n31871.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">hic obsistam, ne, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>will station myself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 3, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui obviam,</quote> <trans><tr>to plant one's self in another's way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsistens obtestansque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plures abeunti Volumnio obsistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31871.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n31871.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To set one's self against; to oppose, resist, withstand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui cum obsistere ac defendere conarentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:43:section=94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 43, § 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnibus ejus consiliis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 7, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:12:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 12, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitiis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 10, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">visis,</quote> <trans><tr>to disapprove of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:9:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 9, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opinionibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 34, 108</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstitit Oceanus in se simul atque in Herculem inquiri,</quote> <trans><tr>opposes, forbids</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 34</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Histiaeus Miletus ne res conficeretur obstitit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstitisti, ne ex Italiā transire in Siciliam fugitivorum copiae possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:2:section=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 2, § 5</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">quominus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae si cui obstitit, quominus referret gratiam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:5:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 5, 3</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnitudine animi facile posset repugnari obsistique fortunae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:7:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 7, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31871.4" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭ-tus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n31871.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Over against, opposite</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">luna radios solis obstiti vel adversi usurpat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Deo Socr. p. 42</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31871.6" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">opposing, inimical;</hi> hence, in augury, <hi rend="ital">struck by lightning</hi>: obstitum Cloatius et Aelius Stilo esse aiunt violatum attactumque de caelo. Cincius quom qui deo deaeque obstiterit id est qui viderit, quod videri nefas esset, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">FVLGVRA ATQVE OBSTITA PIANTO,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:9:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 9, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsitus: <entryFree id="n31872" type="main" key="obsi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from 2. obsero.</entryFree>
obsius: <entryFree id="n31873" type="main" key="Obsi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Obsĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n31873.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 26, 67, § 196</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Obsĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., belonging to Obsius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis,</quote> <trans><tr>so named after the discoverer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:177" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 65, § 177</bibl></cit>.— Also <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:200" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 13, 76, § 200</bibl>; and <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsĭāna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">plur. n., a kind of glass</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsiana numerantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 26, 67, § 196</bibl></cit>. (The older editions of Pliny read Obsidius and Obsidianus; hence the name <hi rend="ital">obsidian</hi> applied to the stone.)</sense></entryFree>
obsolefacio: <entryFree id="n31874" type="main" key="obso^le^fa^ci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlĕfăcĭo</orth>, <itype>fēci, factum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31874.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a.;</hi> in <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlĕfīo</orth>, <itype>factus, fieri</itype> <etym>obsoleofacio</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to wear out, spoil, injure, sully, degrade, lower, make common</hi> (mostly postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">rivi non opere, nec fistulā, nec ullo coacto itinere obsolefacti, sed sponte currentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 90:43" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 90, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auctoritas obsolefacta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:ib. 29:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 29, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">toga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:5:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonebat, ne paterentur nomen suum commissionibus obsolefieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:89" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsolefiebant dignitatis insignia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 41, 105</bibl></cit>; B. and K. dub. (al. obsolescebant; al. obsolebant).</sense></entryFree>
obsolefactus: <entryFree id="n31875" type="main" key="obso^le^factus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlĕfactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obsolefacio.</entryFree>
obsoleo: <entryFree id="n31876" type="main" key="obso^leo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏleo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, v. obsolefacio <sense id="n31876.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obsolesco: <entryFree id="n31877" type="main" key="obso^lesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlesco</orth>, <itype>lēvi, lētum, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31877.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [obs-olesco], <hi rend="ital">to wear out, to grow old, decay, fall into disuse, lose value, become obsolete</hi><pb n="1244" /> <cb n="OBSO" />  (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn. exolesco): his (verbis) oportet, si possis, non uti: sic enim obsolescent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 16</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">haec ne obsolescerent, renovabam, cum licebat, legendo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsolevit jam oratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:17:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 17, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vectigal, quod in bello non obsolescat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">enituit aliquis in bello, sed obsolevit in pace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:4:5" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 4, 5</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlētus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n31877.1" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">old, worn out, thrown off</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">erat veste obsoletā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 8, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amiculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:9:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 9, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestitu obsoletiore, Cig. Agr. 2, 5, 13: homo obsoletus,</quote> <trans><tr>in a worn-out dress</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:Pis. 36:89" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pis. 36, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tectum,</quote> <trans><tr>old, ruinous</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 10, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <trans><tr>obsolete</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:37:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 37, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsoleta et vulgaria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 18, 56</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31877.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">common, ordinary, poor, mean, low</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">crimina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:44:section=177" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 44, § 177</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 42</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsoletior oratio,</quote> <trans><tr>a too ordinary, too negligent style</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:9:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 9, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">honores,</quote> <trans><tr>of little worth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">color,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:30" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o nec paternis obsoleta sordibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:46" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dextra obsoleta sanguine,</quote> <trans><tr>defiled</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 977" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 977</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlētē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in an old</hi> or <hi rend="ital">worn-out style, poorly, meanly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">paulo tamen obsoletius vestitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:58:section=152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 58, § 152</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsoleto: <entryFree id="n31878" type="main" key="obso^le_to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlēto</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>obsoletus</etym>, <sense id="n31878.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to degrade, soil, sully, stain, defile</hi> (eccl. Lat.). </sense><sense id="n31878.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui vestitum obsoletāssent nuptialem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Gnost. 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31878.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">majestatis vestigia obsoletant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsoletus: <entryFree id="n31879" type="main" key="obso^le_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlētus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. obsolesco <sense id="n31879.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
obsolido: <entryFree id="n31880" type="main" key="obso^li^do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlĭdo</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ob-solido</etym>, <sense id="n31880.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make firm</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fast, to harden, consolidate</hi>, only in <hi rend="ital">part. pass.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏlĭdātus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">made solid, firm</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tectorio rigide obsolidato,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsonatio: <entryFree id="n31881" type="main" key="obso_na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. obsono</etym>, <sense id="n31881.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a buying of victuals; a catering, marketing</hi>, Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 2, 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsonator: <entryFree id="n31882" type="main" key="obso_na_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnātor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id..</etym>, <sense id="n31882.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a buyer of victuals; a caterer, purveyor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsonator optimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 73</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:217" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 217</bibl> <hi rend="ital">in lemm.;</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 47:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 47, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsonatus: <entryFree id="n31883" type="main" key="obso_na_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n31883.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a catering, marketing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare minam in obsonatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsonatu redeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit> and 14.</sense></entryFree>
obsonito: <entryFree id="n31884" type="hapax" key="obso_ni^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnĭto</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <sense id="n31884.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq. n.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to feast, entertain</hi>, Cato ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=201" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 201</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
obsonium: <entryFree id="n31885" type="greek" key="obso_ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnĭum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">o)yw/nion</foreign>, <sense id="n31885.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that which is eaten with bread; victuals, viands</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">fish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu facito obsonatum nobis sit opulentum obsonium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 3, 3, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsonare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 3, 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scindere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Vit. Beat. 17:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Vit. Beat. 17, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 7, 41, § 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">coëmere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opsonia rancidula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:134" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 134</bibl></cit>.—Also of <hi rend="ital">fruit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 19, 21, § 82</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obsono: <entryFree id="n31886" type="main" key="obso_no1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōno</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">obsōnor</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ops-</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym><foreign lang="greek">o)ywne/w</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n31886.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to buy provisions, to cater, purvey</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n31886.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam opsonavit erus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 1, 3, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibo atque opsonabo opsonium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 3, 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vix drachmis est opsonatus decem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 6, 20</bibl></cit>.—Dep. form <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 5, 3, 8</bibl>: de suo obsonari filiai nuptiis; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31886.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to feast, treat, to furnish an entertainment</hi>: opsonat, potat, olet unguenta; <cit><quote lang="la">de meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 9, 7</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n31886.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: obsonare ambulando famem, <hi rend="ital">to cater</hi> or <hi rend="ital">provide an appetite</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:34:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 34, 97</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31887" type="main" key="obso^no2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sŏno</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n31887.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to interrupt by a sound;</hi> trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui sermone,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to interrupt by speaking</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 74</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsopesco: <entryFree id="n31888" type="gloss" key="obso^pesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏpesco</orth>, <itype>3</itype>, <sense id="n31888.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to fall asleep</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsopit, obsopitus, obsopesco,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 135</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsopio: <entryFree id="n31889" type="main" key="obso^pi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sŏpĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4</itype>, <sense id="n31889.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to put</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lull to sleep</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">a somni tempore prohibere, ne obsopiantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 180" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 180</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">somno obsopitus,</quote> <trans><tr>fallen asleep</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odoris novitate obsopitus,</quote> <trans><tr>made faint, stupefied</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
obsopitus: <entryFree id="n31890" type="main" key="obso^pi_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obsŏpītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obsopio.</entryFree>
obsorbeo: <entryFree id="n31891" type="main" key="obsorbe^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sorbĕo</orth>, <itype>ŭi, 2</itype>, <sense id="n31891.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to sup</hi> or <hi rend="ital">drink up, to swallow</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gulp down</hi> (poetical). </sense><sense id="n31891.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 34</bibl></cit>: placentas, <hi rend="ital">to gulp down, bolt</hi>, Hor. <cb n="OBST" /> S. 2, 8, 24: <cit><quote lang="la">unionem liquefactum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 35, 58, § 121</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ter die absorbebat, terque eructabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 125" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ursis homines non plane comedendi, sed obsorbendi objectabantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Mort. Pers. 21, 6</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n31891.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">fores, Quae obsorbent quicquid venit intra pessulos,</quote> <trans><tr>swallow up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 3, 29</bibl></cit> (dub.; al. absorbent).</sense></entryFree>
obsordesco: <entryFree id="n31892" type="main" key="obsordesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sordesco</orth>, <itype>dŭi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31892.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n., to become dirty, be soiled</hi> (ante- and post-class.). </sense><sense id="n31892.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne coma fumo obsordescat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 214</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31892.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to wear out, decrease</hi>: obsorduit jam haec in me aerumna, i. e. <hi rend="ital">is moderated</hi>, Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 147, 7</bibl> (Com. Rel. v. 86 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
obstaculum: <entryFree id="n31893" type="main" key="obsta_cu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-stācŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>obsto</etym>, <sense id="n31893.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a hinderance, obstacle</hi> (post-class.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">impedimentum): teneris et rarioribus parcit (fulmen), quia transitu patente minus obstaculum invenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:52:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 52, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumpere obstacula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Ham. 601</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 361, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 62</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 3</bibl>.—In <number>plur.</number>, of <hi rend="ital">mountains</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 21, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obstans: <entryFree id="n31894" type="main" key="obstans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from obsto.</entryFree>
obstantia: <entryFree id="n31895" type="main" key="obstanti^a1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstantĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. obsto <sense id="n31895.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> c.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n31896" type="main" key="obstanti^a2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstantĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obsto</etym>, <sense id="n31896.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a standing before</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against, a resistance, hinderance, obstruction</hi> (only in Vitr.): <cit><quote lang="la">terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aëris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umbrarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obsterno: <entryFree id="n31897" type="main" key="obsterno"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sterno</orth>, <itype>strāvi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31897.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to strew</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cast before, to throw in one's way</hi> (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">uxorem puero,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 335, 31</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obstetricius: <entryFree id="n31898" type="main" key="obste_^tri_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstē^trīcĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">opst-</orth>) or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>obstetrix</etym>, <sense id="n31898.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a midwife, obstetric</hi> (post -Aug.). </sense><sense id="n31898.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">manūs obstetriciae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3, 166</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31898.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Orat. p. 246" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Orat. p. 246</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31898.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstē^-trīcĭa</orth> (sc. officia), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">midwifery, obstetrics</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jove Liberum parturiente inter obstetricia dearum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40, § 140</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obstetrico: <entryFree id="n31899" type="main" key="obste_^tri_co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstē^trīco</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">opst-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n31899.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to perform the office of a midwife</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Nat. 2, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hebraeas (sc. mulieres),</quote> <trans><tr>to assist in childbirth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstetricandi scientia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31899.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">poëtis obstetricantibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Nat. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obstetrix: <entryFree id="n31900" type="main" key="obste_^trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstē^trix</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">opst-</orth>) or <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstī^trix (opst-</orth>), <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obsto</etym>, <sense id="n31900.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a midwife</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">peperit Sine obstetricis operā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 2, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 96</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mittere ad obstetricem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:51" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 1, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstetricum nobilitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 6, 18, § 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 2, 24, 8 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
obstinate: <entryFree id="n31901" type="main" key="obsti^na_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭnātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. obstino, <sense id="n31901.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
obstinatio: <entryFree id="n31902" type="main" key="obsti^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>obstino</etym>, <sense id="n31902.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">firmness</hi>, in a good and bad sense; <hi rend="ital">resolution, steadfastness, determination, inflexibility, stubbornness, obstinacy</hi> (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: pertinacia, contumacia): quae ego omnia obstinatione sententiae repudiavi,</quote> <trans><tr>out of adherence to my principles</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:17:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Prov. Cons. 17, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 94:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 94, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fidei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">taciturna,</quote> <trans><tr>obstinate silence</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:22:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 22, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inflexibilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:97:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 97, 3</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Nat. 1, 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obstinatus: <entryFree id="n31903" type="main" key="obsti^na_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭnātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from obstino.</entryFree>
obstinet: <entryFree id="n31904" type="main" key="obsti^net"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭnet</orth> <itype>dicebant antiqui, quod nunc ostendit</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=197" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 197</bibl> Müll.; so, iam se caelo cedens aurora obstinet suum patrem, Poët. ib. (Trag. Rel. p. 228 Rib.).</entryFree>
obstino: <entryFree id="n31905" type="main" key="obsti^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>a lengthened form of obsto</etym>, <sense id="n31905.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to set about</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">with firmness</hi> or <hi rend="ital">resolution, to set one's mind firmly on, to persist in, be resolved on a</hi> thing (as a <hi rend="ital">verb. fin.</hi> very rare; only the <mood>Part.</mood> as a <pos>P. a.</pos> is freq.). </sense><sense id="n31905.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">id inhiat, ea affinitatem hanc obstinavit gratia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 89</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: obstinari exorsus, Pac. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 425 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n31905.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstinaverant animis aut vincere, aut mori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:29:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 29, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31905.3" n="(g)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipso Vespasiano inter initia imperii ad obtinendas iniquitates haud perinde obstinante,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 84</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭnātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., firmly set, fixed, resolved</hi>, in a good or bad sense; <hi rend="ital">determined, resolute, steadfast, inflexible, stubborn, obstinate</hi> (class.; syn.: pervicax, pertinax): vos qui astatis obstinati, Naev. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 11 Rib.): obstinato animo aliquid facere, Att. ap. Paul. ex Fest. l. l. (Trag. Rel. p. 123 Rib.); <cit><quote lang="la">so,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ruth, 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad decertandum obstinati animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad silendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:1:30" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cb n="OBST" /> ad mortem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:41:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 41, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus lacrimas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:40:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 40, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:47:4" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 47, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad resistendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra veritatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pudicitia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aures,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:11:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 11, 7</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam obstinatis mori spes affulsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:21:1" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 21, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:25:6" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 25, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstinatum est tibi, non suscipere imperium, nisi, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>you are firmly resolved</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:5:6" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 5, 6</bibl></cit>.—Rarely with <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstinatae in perniciem Romae urbes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 11, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in extrema,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">militum animos obstinatos pro Vitellio subruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 101</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntas obstinatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 11, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus lacrimas muliebres,</quote> <trans><tr>firmer, more steadfast</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 40</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtus obstinatissima,</quote> <trans><tr>the most resolute</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 71:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 71, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rex obstinatissimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 14</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭ-nātē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">firmly, inflexibly</hi>, in a good and bad sense; <hi rend="ital">resolutely, pertinaciously, stubbornly, obstinately</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ita me obstinate aggressus, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">operam dat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magis ac magis induruisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:12:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 12, 10</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstinatius omnia agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:29" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 29</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstinatissime recusare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:67" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 67</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
obstipatio: <entryFree id="n31906" type="main" key="obsti_pa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstīpātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ob-stipo</etym>, <sense id="n31906.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the close pressure</hi> (eccl. Lat.): turbarum obstipatione, Laurent. Hom. 1.</sense></entryFree>
obstipesco: <entryFree id="n31907" type="main" key="obsti^pesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-stĭpesco</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-stŭpesco</orth>, <itype>pŭi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n31907.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a., to become senseless, lose feeling; to be stupefied, benumbed</hi> (syn.: obtorpesco; class.). </sense><sense id="n31907.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">apes obstupescunt potantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 7, 11, § 56</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31907.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to be astonished, astounded, amazed, to be struck with amazement</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid hic, malum, adstans obstipuisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob haec beneficia, quibus illi obstupescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 21, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ejus aspectu cum obstupuisset bubulcus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:23:50" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 23, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">visu Aeneas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstupuerunt stupore magno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:5:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 5, 42</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n31907.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc., to wonder</hi> or <hi rend="ital">be astonished at</hi> any thing (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 2, 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
obstipus: <entryFree id="n31908" type="main" key="obsti_pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstīpus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ob-stipes</etym>, <sense id="n31908.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">bent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inclined to one side;</hi> opp. to rectus (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n31908.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">oblique, shelving</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia mendose fieri atque obstipa, necesse est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4</bibl></cit>. 517: obstitum (leg. obstipum) obliquum, Enn. Libr. XVI.: montibus obstitis (leg. obstipis) obstantibus, unde oritur nox. Et in Libr. VIII.: amplius exaugere obstipolumve (leg. opstipo lumine) solis. Caecilius in imbros (leg. Imbris): resupina obstito (leg. obstipo) capitulo sibi ventum facere cunicula (leg. tunicula). Lucretius: omnia, etc.; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">supra</ref></xr>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll.; v. Müll. ad loc.; and cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:v. 290" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Ann. v. 290</bibl> and 407 Vahl.; and Trag. Rel. p. 44 Rib.—</sense><sense id="n31908.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n31908.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Bent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">drawn back</hi>, said of the stiff neck of a proud person: <cit><quote lang="la">cervix rigida et obstipa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 68</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31908.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Bent forward, bent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bowed down</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stes capite obstipo, multum similis metuenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 92</bibl></cit>.—So of one lost in thought: <cit><quote lang="la">obstipo capite et figentes lumine terram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:3:80" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 3, 80</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31908.5" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Bent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inclined to one side</hi>, of the dragon's head, a translation of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">loco\n ka/rh</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstipum caput et tereti cervice reflexum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,060:N. D. 2:42:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Arat. N. D. 2, 42, 107</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:10:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 10, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n31908.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">stiff - necked, obstinate, perverse</hi> (eccl. Lat.), Jul. ap. Aug. c. Sec. Resp. Jul. 3, 38.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstīpē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">adv., perversely</hi>, Jul. ap. Aug. c. Sec. Resp. Jul. 6, 25.</sense></entryFree>
obstitus: <entryFree id="n31909" type="main" key="obsti_tus1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. obstipus.</entryFree>
<entryFree id="n31910" type="main" key="obsti^tus2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">obstĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. obsisto, II. B.</entryFree>
obsto: <entryFree id="n31911" type="main" key="obsto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ob-sto</orth>, <itype>stĭti, ātum</itype> (obstaturus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aquaed. 123" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aquaed. 123</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:11:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:247" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 247</bibl>; <sense id="n31911.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> obstantum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:5:277" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 5, 277</bibl>), 1, <hi rend="ital">v. n., to stand before</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi> any thing. </sense><sense id="n31911.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (very rare): soli luna obstitit, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:16:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 16, 25</bibl> (Ann. v. 167 Vahl.); cf.: montibus obstipis obstantibus, id. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 407 ib.): <cit><quote lang="la">dominae niveis a vultibus obstas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:2:23" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 2, 23</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">summis a postibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Th. 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obviam,</quote> <trans><tr>to stand in the way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 1, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31911.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">to stand against</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in the way of</hi> a person or thing; <hi rend="ital">to withstand, thwart, hinder, oppose, obstruct</hi> (the class. signif. of the word; syn.: obsisto, adversor, officio).—Constr. with <hi rend="ital">dat., absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">quin, quominus, cur</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">ne.</hi> </sense><sense id="n31911.3" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae tardis mora noctibus obstet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:746" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 746</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: cur <pb n="1245" /> <cb n="OBST" /> mihi te offers ac meis commodis officis et obstas? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:38:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 38, 112</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita cetera eorum huic sceleri obstat,</quote> <trans><tr>their former life stands opposed to this crime, secures them against the suspicion of this crime</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">di omnes quibus obstitit Ilium,</quote> <trans><tr>was an offence to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam sic labentibus (aedibus) obstat vilicus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>keeps from falling</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:194" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 194</bibl></cit>; cf. v. 243.—For the <hi rend="ital">dat. in</hi> with <case>acc.</case> is found: <cit><quote lang="la">in laudem vetustorum invidia non obstat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 7:8:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 7, 8, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31911.4" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: me obstare, illos obsequi, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:31:66" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 31, 66</bibl>: restitant, occurrunt, obstant, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 147, 9</bibl> (Sat. v. 5 ib.): <cit><quote lang="la">obstando magis quam pugnando castra tutabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40</bibl></cit> 25: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitus hostium duo obstant,</quote> <trans><tr>block up the way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 58:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 58, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 1, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si omnia removentur, quae obstant et impediunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 7, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31911.5" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">quin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus non humana ulla, neque divina obstant, quin socios amicos trahant, exscindant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 4:61:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 4, 61, 17</bibl></cit> Dietsch.—</sense><sense id="n31911.6" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">quominus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid obstat, quominus sit beatus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:34:95" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 34, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quid divini humanive obstet, quominus justum piumque de integro ineatur bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 8, 6</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">cur</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid obstat, cur non (verae nuptiae) fiant?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 76</bibl></cit>.— (<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Histiaeus Milesius, ne res conficeretur, obstitit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ibi quoque religio obstaret, ne non posset nisi ab consule dici dictator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:31:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 31, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne id, quod placebat, decerneret in tantae nobilitatis viris, ambitio obstabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:36:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 36, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31911.7" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Impers. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec, si non obstatur, propterea etiam permittitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indignatur amans Obstari animae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:788" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 788</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n31911.8" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Part. pres.</hi> in <number>plur.</number> as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">obstantia</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstantia silvarum
